pages:
Assam Skill University Project (RRP IND 53277-002)  
 
Technical Assistance Report  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 53277-002 
Transaction Technical Assistance (TRTA) 
November 2021 
 
 
 
India: Supporting the Development of Higher-Level 
Skills and Entrepreneurship 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Distribution of this document is restricted until it has been approved by the Board of Directors. 
Following such approval, ADB will disclose the document to the public in accordance with ADB's 
Access to Information Policy.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 12 October 2021) 
 
Currency unit  –  Indian rupee/s (₹)  
₹1.00  =  $0.013 
$1.00  =  ₹75.38 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ASU  –  Assam Skill University 
  ITI  –  industrial training institute 
  JFPR  –  Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
  MSMEs  –  micro-, small-, and medium-sized enterprises 
  NSQF  –  National Skills Qualification Framework 
  R&D  –  research and development 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TVET  –  technical and vocational education and training 
 
 
NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government of India, the Government of Assam, and 
their agencies ends on 31 March. “FY” before a calendar year denotes the year in 
which the fiscal year ends, e.g., FY2021 ends on 31 March 2021.  
(ii)  In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

Vice-President  Shixin Chen, Operations 1 
Director General  Kenichi Yokoyama, South Asia Department (SARD)

Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

CONTENTS 
Page 
I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT  1 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  1 
A.  Justification  1 
B.  Outputs and Activities  3 
C.  Cost and Financing  4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  5 
 
APPENDIXES 
1.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan  6 
2.  List of Linked Documents  7

I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  Assam is the largest state in the North Eastern Region of India in terms of economy and 
population and occupies a strategic position for various regional cooperation programs in South 
Asia and Southeast Asia.1 Despite its abundant natural resources and higher proportion of young 
population (under 40 years of age) than the rest of India, Assam has yet to unleash its growth 
potential. Assam is landlocked and largely rural, and has underdeveloped infrastructure, and its 
economy is dominated by low value-added, natural resource-based products and is poorly 
integrated with regional and global value chains. Its manufacturing sectors are undiversified and 
small in terms of outputs and capital investment. Studies conducted by the Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB)  indicate  that  aggressive  infrastructure  and  industrial  development,  specifically, 
corridor-based industrial development, is necessary for Assam to grow its economy. However, 
they identify limited availability of a skilled workforce as one of the constraints.2 Fewer prospects 
for socioeconomic development have propelled out-migration for jobs and education, leading to 
shortages of higher-level skills in Assam. Technical and vocational education and training (TVET) 
and higher education are undersupplied, and face many challenges, including (i) low quality and 
low industry relevance of education and training programs, leading to poor employability of 
graduates  from  industrial  training  institutes  (ITIs),  polytechnics,  engineering  colleges,  and 
academic colleges and universities; and (ii) inadequate training systems for trainers and faculty 
of ITIs and polytechnics. 
 
2.  The Assam Skill University Project will assist the Government of Assam in strengthening 
the industry-aligned and flexible skills education and training system in Assam through the 
establishment of a skill university. The project will have five outputs: (i) university management 
and operating systems, business models, and faculty development and management systems 
developed; (ii) environmentally sustainable and climate-resilient university campus and facilities 
developed; (iii) industry-aligned and flexible skills education and training programs designed and 
delivered;  (iv)  capacity  to  manage  and  support  entrepreneurship,  applied  research  and 
development  (R&D),  and  technology  transfer  developed;  and  (v)  access  to  professional 
development and quality skills education and training resources improved. The project is aligned 
with the following impacts: decent employment for all ensured, and inclusive and sustainable 
infrastructure and industrial development accelerated. The Government of India has requested a 
regular loan of $112 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to help finance the project. The 
project is included in ADB’s country operations business plan for India, 2021–2023.3 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  Assam was home to about 24.8 million people aged 15 years and above (49% women) in 
2018, of which more than 11.4 million (46%) were in the labor force (84% in rural areas), and 10.6 
million (93% of the labor force) were employed.4 The share of nonfarm employment grew steadily, 
 
1  For example, the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation program, the Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-
Sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation, and the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation. 
2  ADB. 2021. Assam as India’s Gateway to ASEAN. Manila; and ADB. 2021. North East Economic Corridor: Bringing 
People and Markets Together. Presentation prepared for the virtual workshops on North East Economic Corridor 
study organized in collaboration with the Government of India’s Department of Promotion of Industry and Internal 
Trade. 20 April; 18, 25 and 30 June; and 5 July 2021. 
3  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: India, 2021–2023. Manila.   
4  The labor force includes those who are working, willing to work, or actively looking for work. National Skill 
Development Corporation. 2019. Estimating the Skill Stock in Assam. New Delhi.

2 
from 32% in 2005 to 44% in 2012, and to 77% in 2018.5 Educational attainment of the population 
remains low: in 2018, 82% of the population aged 15 years and above received education only 
up to grade 10 and below, or did not receive education at all, while 13% attained grades 11–12, 
and barely 5% completed higher education.6 The incidence of poverty in the state remains higher 
than the national average.7 These issues are further compounded by the state’s vulnerability to 
natural hazards such as cyclonic storms and floods, which are likely to intensify because of 
climate change. 
 
4.  Lack of pathways for progression and mobility. The TVET and higher education 
systems in Assam do not provide pathways for progression and mobility. In fiscal year (FY) 2019, 
the TVET and higher education systems in Assam comprised (i) 36 ITIs offering courses leading 
to the National Skills Qualification Framework (NSQF) levels 3–5 certificates, (ii) 23 polytechnics 
offering diploma courses, (iii) 46 engineering colleges offering engineering degree programs, and 
(iv) 544 colleges and 22 universities offering diplomas and academic degree programs. More than 
10 academic colleges and universities also offer programs leading to NSQF level 7 bachelor of 
vocation degrees and level 9 master of vocation degrees, but the uptake of these programs has 
been minimal without adequate pathways for progression and mobility between different types of 
institutions. ITIs and polytechnics are generally perceived by youth as less attractive options than 
degree-granting engineering and academic institutions because few opportunities are available 
for graduates from ITIs and polytechnics for upskilling and pursuing further study. On the other 
hand,  graduates  from  engineering  and  academic  colleges  and  universities  have  limited 
opportunities for employment-oriented skills development. 
 
5.  Skill universities. Against this background, the National Policy for Skill Development and 
Entrepreneurship 2015 envisaged the establishment of “skill universities”.8 Skill universities are 
intended to offer industry-aligned skills education and training programs with multiple entry and 
exit options leading to NSQF level 4 qualifications and above. They are integrated with higher 
education to create pathways for progression and mobility. Skill universities are also expected to 
conduct industry-relevant applied R&D, train trainers and faculty of ITIs and polytechnics, and 
promote quality and industry relevance of training courses and programs provided by various 
institutions as a hub. The concept of skill universities anticipated the National Education Policy 
2020, which sets out to reform the higher education system into a multidisciplinary and flexible 
system with multiple entry and exit points, by integrating professional education and TVET.9 
 
6.  Assam Skill University. In September 2020, the Assam Legislative Assembly passed the 
Assam Skill University Act to establish Assam Skill University (ASU) in compliance with the 
regulations of the Government of India’s University Grants Commission. The Government of 
Assam envisages ASU to (i) distinguish itself as a premium institution with its campus and facilities 
equipped with the state-of-the-art technologies; (ii) fill critical gaps in high-quality, industry-
aligned, and flexible skill education and training integrated with higher education; (iii) conduct 
applied R&D and technology transfer; (iv) support entrepreneurship and business startups; and 
(v) raise skill levels to enhance the productivity and competitiveness of various industries in 
 
5  The 2005 and 2012 data are from World Bank Group. 2017. Assam: Jobs. New Delhi. The 2018 data are from the 
National Skill Development Corporation.  
6  National Skill Development Corporation. 2019. Estimating the Skill Stock in Assam. New Delhi. 
7  The poverty headcount ratio in Assam in 2013 was estimated to be 37.1%, higher than the national average of 21.9%. 
Government of Assam, Transformation and Development Department. 2018. Economic Survey of Assam 2017–
2018. Guwahati. 
8  Government  of  India,  Ministry  of  Skill  Development  and  Entrepreneurship.  2015.  National  Policy  for  Skill 
Development and Entrepreneurship 2015. New Delhi. 
9  Ministry of Human Resource Development. 2020. National Education Policy 2020. New Delhi.

3 
Assam and the North Eastern Region. The state government also expects ASU to cater for the 
needs  of  students;  TVET  and  higher  education  institutions;  and  industries  in  neighboring 
countries, which face similar challenges in skills education and training, and with which the state 
has long-standing relationships. ASU will be located about 74 kilometers east of Guwahati, and 
falling within 25 kilometers of National Highway 27 connecting Guwahati with other major cities in 
Assam. National Highway 27 is integrated with other modes of transport (i.e., airways, waterways, 
and railways) and provides important connectivity to neighboring states and countries. 
 
7.  The  transaction  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  assist  the  Government  of  Assam  in 
establishing  ASU  as  a  premium  institution  through  research,  policy  advice,  and  capacity 
development. Technical assessments conducted for the project have identified gaps in the 
expertise and capacity available within the state government, especially against a background of 
rapidly evolving markets for technologies in areas such as environmentally sustainable and 
climate-resilient building and facility design and management; and teaching, learning, and career 
management, especially in the context of post-coronavirus disease pandemic recovery. The 
capacity and resources for skills education and training and applied R&D also need to be 
developed in fields of common interest where ASU can collaborate with other TVET and higher 
education institutions in neighboring countries. To maximize its impacts on the local economy, 
ASU needs to develop programs and facilities that cater to the needs of local entrepreneurs; 
startups;  and micro,  small,  and medium-sized  enterprises (MSMEs) for  technology,  digital, 
business, and skilling solutions. The TA was requested to develop the capacity of and provide 
expertise currently unavailable to the state government for the establishment of ASU as a 
premium institution in the medium term. Meanwhile, to lay the foundations of ASU in the short 
term, the project will support (i) the development of the ASU campus and facilities; (ii) ASU’s 
management and operating systems; (iii) the capacity of ASU’s management, faculty, and staff 
members; and (iv) ASU’s core skills education and training programs. 
 
8.  Lessons. Lessons from ongoing TA in support of skills development projects in India have 
been  incorporated  into  the  design  of  this  TA,  including  the  importance  of  (i)  introducing 
international best practices in TVET infrastructure development, curriculum design, training of 
trainers, and quality assurance by facilitating partnerships with TVET institutions abroad; and (ii) 
conducting in-depth market research on emerging technologies and industries to inform the 
design and management of TVET infrastructure and skills development programs.10 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
9.  Output  1:  Environmentally  sustainable  and  climate-resilient  design  and 
management systems for university campus and facilities introduced. The TA will support 
ASU management and administration teams to (i) review the detailed design and engineering 
drawings of the ASU campus and facilities, which will be prepared by the civil works contractor 
engaged under the loan; and (ii) ensure that ASU campus and facilities are designed to maximize 
environmental sustainability and climate resilience by adopting green building standards, energy- 
and water-saving systems, and climate adaptation measures. The preparation of a sustainable 
campus and facility management strategy to reduce emissions and enhance energy and resource 
efficiency and climate resilience will be also supported. The TA will further assist ASU teams in 
examining and determining appropriate information technology and other technology solutions to 
 
10 ADB. 2017. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and 
Administration of Technical Assistance Grant to India for the Odisha Skill Development Project. Manila; and ADB. 
2019. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and Administration of 
Technical Assistance Grant to India for the Madhya Pradesh Skills Development Project. Manila.

4 
manage the ASU campus and facilities in an integrated manner (through a digital and/or smart 
campus platform) and to enhance environmental sustainability and climate resilience. 
 
10.  Output  2:  Integrated  teaching,  learning,  and  career  development  management 
platform designed. The TA will support research on the market for digital platforms that integrate 
labor market intelligence (i.e., analysis and forecasting of demand for skills); learning and career 
development advisory services; learner performance monitoring; and curriculum, content, and 
instructional strategy management. Based on the market research, the TA will assist ASU’s 
management, faculty, and administration teams in preparing functional and system requirements 
and specifications for ASU’s teaching, learning, and career development management system 
integrated with the digital campus platform, which will be used for managing and delivering skills 
education and training programs aligned with the NSQF, as well as other advanced skills, career 
development, soft skills, and language skills programs to be established at ASU.  
 
11.  Output  3:  Skills  education  and  training  programs  and  applied  research  and 
development  projects  addressing infrastructure  and  industrial  development  needs in 
neighboring countries developed. The TA will support partnership activities between ASU and 
leading institutes, universities, and enterprises in India and abroad to develop curricula, training 
materials and facilities, assessments, and skills of faculty and staff members for skills education 
and  training  programs  and  applied  R&D  projects  that  address  infrastructure  and  industrial 
development needs in neighboring countries (e.g., Bangladesh, Bhutan, and Nepal). Fields of 
common interest such as regional connectivity (e.g., logistics); regional market development and 
integration  (e.g.,  value-added  bamboo  products,  and  medical  and  wellness  tourism);  and 
environmental sustainability will be prioritized. Common modules on environmental sustainability 
and climate change to be integrated into all skills education and training programs at ASU will 
also be developed, as well as career development, soft skills, and language skills programs. 
Through partnership activities, the TA will also strengthen the capacity of leadership and staff 
members at ASU’s international partnership office to develop, manage, and sustain partnerships, 
especially with TVET and higher education institutions in neighboring countries. 
 
12.  Output 4: Capacity to support entrepreneurship and business startups; and micro, 
small, and medium-sized enterprises developed. The TA will support feasibility studies for the 
establishment of incubator and accelerator programs and facilities for technology services, 
applied R&D, testing, and certification at ASU (in areas such as environmental sustainability) in 
partnership with leading institutes, universities, and enterprises in India and abroad to support 
entrepreneurship and business startups as well as MSMEs in Assam. Based on the studies, 
detailed road maps to establish those programs and facilities that cater to the needs of local 
entrepreneurs, startups, and MSMEs for technology, digital, business, and skilling solutions will 
be  prepared.  The  TA  will  also  support  the  preparation  of  an  entrepreneurial  competency 
framework and a plan for developing entrepreneurship education and support programs for the 
other faculties at ASU, as well as common entrepreneurship modules to be integrated into all 
skills education and training programs and resource materials for faculty and students. Further, 
the  TA  will  build  the  capacity  of  leadership,  faculty,  and  staff  at  ASU’s  office  of  industry 
engagement and commercial ventures to establish and manage networks of industry partners, 
alumni, business support, and funding organizations.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.25 million, of which $1.00 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) and administered by ADB and $0.15 
million by the Climate Change Fund. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. Ineligible

5 
under JFPR are: (i) purchase of vehicles, (ii) salaries for civil servants, (iii) foreign travels of the 
beneficiary, (iv) scholarships or long internships, (v) detailed engineering design, (vi) civil works 
and other related expenses, and (vii) those under ADB’s Prohibited Investment Activities List in 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). The government will provide counterpart support in 
the form of counterpart staff, meeting space, information, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. The Skill, Employment and Entrepreneurship Department of 
the Government of Assam will be the executing agency and will provide overall direction and 
guidance for TA implementation. The Assam Skill Development Mission, which will be the 
implementing  agency,  has  established  a  project  management  unit  that  will  manage  and 
coordinate day-to-day TA activities and provide guidance and support to consultants engaged 
under the TA. The TA will be implemented for 3 years. ADB (through its South Asia Department) 
will  select,  supervise,  and  evaluate  consultants.  The  implementation  arrangements  are 
summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  December 2021–December 2024 
Executing agency  Skill, Employment and Entrepreneurship Department 
Implementing agency  Assam Skill Development Mission 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by the Asian Development Bank 
Quality- and cost- Smart campus management;  $428,600 
based selection  environmental industry analysis 
(28 person-months) 
Individual consultant  International (22 person-months)  $484,750 
selection 
Individual consultant  National (22 person-months)  $200,400 
selection 
Disbursement  Disbursement of TA resources will follow the Asian Development Bank's 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time 
to time). 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.11 
 
16.  Cofinancier requirements. Monitoring, reporting, and visibility requirements will follow 
the JFPR guidelines and applicable ADB project administration and staff instructions. The TA will 
draw on expertise from the Japan International Cooperation Agency, the Embassy of Japan in 
India, and universities and enterprises in Japan. The information on progress in TA activities and 
reports produced under the TA will be shared with the Japan International Cooperation Agency 
and the Embassy of Japan in India. Any changes in TA implementation arrangements and scope 
will be discussed with the JFPR team and will be made in compliance with the JFPR guidelines. 
 
11 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).
